title: 110_hr6560
content: The Earned Import Allowance Program is added to the Dominican Republic-Central America-United States Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The Earned Import Allowance Program allows eligible apparel articles from an eligible country to enter the US duty-free, regardless of fabric source, if accompanied by an import allowance certificate. The program is established under the Dominican Republic-Central America-United States Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The Department of Commerce will establish an Earned Import Allowance Program to provide import certificates to producers in eligible countries based on fabric purchases for manufacturing eligible apparel articles. The Earned Import Allowance Program allows producers in eligible countries to create and maintain an account for credits, redeemable for import allowance certificates. Textile mills in the US can submit documentation verifying export of qualifying fabric to eligible countries. The Earned Import Allowance Program allows producers in eligible countries to control production and identify entities for qualifying fabric exports. The Secretary of Commerce may require documentation for fabric purchases and provide information to relevant parties. The program aims for electronic submission, storage, retrieval, and disclosure of information. The Earned Import Allowance Program facilitates electronic submission, storage, retrieval, and disclosure of information. The Secretary of Commerce can reconcile discrepancies, verify accuracy, and establish procedures for the program by September 30, 2008. Definitions for terms like 'appropriate congressional committees' and 'eligible apparel articles' are provided. The Earned Import Allowance Program defines terms like 'eligible apparel articles' as specific clothing items made of cotton, 'eligible country' as the Dominican Republic, and 'qualifying fabric' as cotton fabric made in the US. The fabric can still qualify even if it contains nylon filament yarn subject to certain conditions. Fabric with yarns not wholly made in the US can still qualify if the total weight of those yarns is less than 10% of the fabric's weight. Additionally, fabric with designated yarns or fibers not commercially available may still be eligible. Fabric with designated yarns or fibers not commercially available may still qualify under specific conditions outlined in various trade agreements. The United States International Trade Commission conducts an annual review of a program for evaluating its effectiveness and making recommendations for improvements. A report on the review results is submitted to congressional committees. The program is effective for a 10-year period after the President certifies certain sections of a proclamation have taken effect. Presidential Proclamation 8213 (December 20, 2007) has taken effect for the program under this section, applying to qualifying fabric exported to eligible countries after August 1, 2007. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents for the Dominican Republic-Central America-United States Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. SEC. 404. Earned import allowance program under the African Growth and Opportunity Act. Section 112 of the African Growth and Opportunity Act is amended to correct a typographical error and redefine the term 'lesser developed beneficiary sub-Saharan African country' based on per capita gross national product criteria. The African Growth and Opportunity Act is amended to include Botswana, Namibia, and Mauritius as countries with a per capita gross national product of less than $1,500 in 1998. The United States International Trade Commission will review and report on textile and apparel inputs that can be competitively produced in beneficiary sub-Saharan African countries. The United States International Trade Commission will submit a report to congressional committees and the Comptroller General on the review of trade preference programs, including the African Growth and Opportunity Act, to enhance competitiveness in textile and apparel production in beneficiary sub-Saharan African countries. The report will include information on yarns, fabrics, and other textile inputs for textile and apparel production in beneficiary sub-Saharan African countries. Definitions for "appropriate congressional committees" and "beneficiary sub-Saharan African countries" are provided. A clerical amendment is made to Public Law 109-432. SEC. 3. Generalized System of Preferences amended to extend deadline to December 31, 2009. SEC. 4. Customs user fees deadlines amended to January 31, 2018. Repeal of certain sections in the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008. SEC. 5. Increase in corporate estimated taxes percentage by 1.75 points. SEC. 6. Technical corrections made. SEC. 6. Technical corrections made to the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008, amending the term "Carribean" to "Caribbean" and correcting a subsection reference from "231A(b)" to "213A(b)."
